articles.headline: Bowe Bergdahl to Face Court-Martial on Desertion Charges
articles.snippet: The charges against Sergeant Bergdahl stemmed from his decision to leave his outpost in Afghanistan, prompting a huge search and landing him in Taliban captivity.
articles.abstract: The charges against Sergeant Bergdahl stemmed from his decision to leave his outpost in Afghanistan, prompting a huge search and landing him in Taliban captivity.
articles.lead_paragraph: A top Army commander on Monday ordered that Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl face a court-martial on charges of desertion and endangering troops stemming from his decision to leave his outpost in 2009, a move that prompted a huge manhunt in the wilds of eastern Afghanistan and landed him in nearly five years of harsh Taliban captivity.

articles.headline: Samsung’s Patent Loss to Apple Is Appealed to Supreme Court
articles.snippet: Samsung has filed an appeal to the Supreme Court, arguing that the legal framework for design patents is an issue larger than its dispute with Apple.
articles.abstract: Samsung has filed an appeal to the Supreme Court, arguing that the legal framework for design patents is an issue larger than its dispute with Apple.
articles.lead_paragraph: Less than two weeks ago, Samsung agreed to pay Apple $548 million in damages in Federal District Court, as their yearslong legal conflict seemed to be tailing off to a cease-fire.

articles.headline: E.P.A. Broke Law With Social Media Push for Water Rule, Auditor Finds
articles.snippet: The agency essentially became a lobbyist for its clean-water cause by directing people to advocacy organizations, the Government Accountability Office said.
articles.abstract: The agency essentially became a lobbyist for its clean-water cause by directing people to advocacy organizations, the Government Accountability Office said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Environmental Protection Agency engaged in “covert propaganda” and violated federal law when it blitzed social media to urge the public to back an Obama administration rule intended to better protect the nation’s streams and surface waters, congressional auditors have concluded.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: Craft Brewers Have to Compete for Beer Cans
articles.snippet: An explosion of popularity for craft brews in 16-ounce cans has led to a shortage of containers for some small breweries.
articles.abstract: An explosion of popularity for craft brews in 16-ounce cans has led to a shortage of containers for some small breweries.
articles.lead_paragraph: When customers began to line up at 5 a.m. outside Scott Metzger’s microbrewery in San Antonio, Mr. Metzger knew he had to start making more beer.

articles.headline: A Mansion, a Shell Company and Resentment in Bel Air
articles.snippet: In the booming high-end market of Los Angeles, where hidden ownership is common, one house stands out.
articles.abstract: In the booming high-end market of Los Angeles, where hidden ownership is common, one house stands out.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The most notorious new house in Los Angeles hangs from a Bel Air hillside, high above the sprawl and smog, unfinished and unloved.

articles.headline: Low Natural Gas Prices Squeeze Industry and Fell a C.E.O.
articles.snippet: The future of the global natural gas markets was at the heart of Charif Souki’s dismissal as chief executive of Cheniere Energy in one of the industry’s latest shake-ups.
articles.abstract: The future of the global natural gas markets was at the heart of Charif Souki’s dismissal as chief executive of Cheniere Energy in one of the industry’s latest shake-ups.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Plummeting oil and natural gas prices have whipsawed the energy industry, forcing cancellations of billions of dollars of projects, late payments on loans, and over a quarter of a million layoffs worldwide.

articles.headline: Diagnosing Yahoo’s Ills: Ugly Math in Marissa Mayer’s Reign
articles.snippet: Investors think Yahoo’s core business is less than worthless. Is it Ms. Mayer’s fault?
articles.abstract: Investors think Yahoo’s core business is less than worthless. Is it Ms. Mayer’s fault?
articles.lead_paragraph: Let’s do some basic math about Yahoo since Marissa Mayer took the helm over three years ago.

articles.headline: Europe Approves Tough New Data Protection Rules
articles.snippet: The changes under review, which include penalties of up to 4 percent of a company’s global revenue, are expected to go into effect by early 2017.
articles.abstract: The changes under review, which include penalties of up to 4 percent of a company’s global revenue, are expected to go into effect by early 2017.
articles.lead_paragraph: European officials approved long-awaited data protection regulations on Tuesday, the latest effort in the region to give people a greater say over how their digital information is collected and managed.

articles.headline: Los Angeles and New York Differ in Their Responses to a Terrorism Threat
articles.snippet: After shutting down the nation’s second-largest school system, officials determined that emailed threats of an attack were probably a hoax. New York City officials dismissed a similar threat as such.
articles.abstract: After shutting down the nation’s second-largest school system, officials determined that emailed threats of an attack were probably a hoax. New York City officials dismissed a similar threat as such.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The nation’s two largest school systems confronted threats of a terrorist attack on Tuesday and reacted in sharply different ways: New York City reviewed the warning and dismissed it as a hoax, but officials here abruptly shut down all public schools, upending the lives of parents, students and teachers.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney, Richard Pérez-Peña and J. David Goodman
